description: From Ottoman Turkish سرعسكر‎ (serasker), from Persian سرعسکر‎ (sar'askar), a compound word from Persian سر‎ (sar, “head”) and Arabic عَسْكَر‎ (ʕaskar, “army”), itself from Persian لشکر‎ (laškar, “army”).

entries.meaning: (now historical) A commander in the Ottoman Empire.
examples: A seraskier or officer took a liking to me here, and wanted me to stay, and offered me two wives; however I resisted the temptation.
